questions.text: What physical quantity is reconstructed in CT, PET, and MRI respectively?
questions.answer: CT reconstructs the X-ray attenuation coefficient (Î¼). PET reconstructs the tracer activity distribution (radioactivity concentration). MRI reconstructs signal intensity related to proton density and relaxation times (T1, T2).

questions.text: Why does PET generally have lower spatial resolution than CT?
questions.answer: PET resolution is limited by positron range, annihilation physics, detector size, and lack of physical collimation, whereas CT uses tightly collimated X-ray beams and high-resolution detectors.

questions.text: Explain why ultrasound image quality depends strongly on operator skill.
questions.answer: Ultrasound acquisition depends on probe position, angle, pressure, and parameter settings such as frequency and gain, all of which directly affect beam propagation and echo formation.

questions.text: Two ultrasound images are acquired at 3 MHz and 12 MHz. Which one has higher penetration and why?
questions.answer: The 3 MHz image has higher penetration because attenuation increases with frequency, while the 12 MHz image provides higher spatial resolution but lower penetration.

questions.text: Why is speckle noise fundamentally different from electronic noise in ultrasound?
questions.answer: Speckle arises from coherent interference of scattered ultrasound waves and is signal-dependent, whereas electronic noise is random and independent of tissue structure.

questions.text: Explain why Non-Local Means filtering preserves edges better than mean filtering in ultrasound.
questions.answer: Non-Local Means uses patch similarity rather than spatial proximity, allowing it to average similar structures while preserving edges, whereas mean filtering blurs edges by averaging local neighbors.

questions.text: Why is normalized cross-correlation preferred over sum of absolute differences for speckle tracking?
questions.answer: Normalized cross-correlation is robust to intensity and gain changes, which commonly occur in ultrasound due to attenuation and system settings, while SAD is sensitive to brightness variations.

questions.text: What does the Dice score measure, and when can it be misleading?
questions.answer: The Dice score measures volumetric overlap between segmentations. It can be misleading when boundary accuracy is important, as large overlaps can hide poor boundary alignment.

questions.text: Why does filtered backprojection require a high-pass (ramp) filter?
questions.answer: Backprojection overemphasizes low frequencies, causing image blurring. The ramp filter compensates by amplifying high frequencies to restore spatial resolution.

questions.text: Explain why CT is usually the first imaging modality in acute stroke.
questions.answer: Non-contrast CT is fast, widely available, and reliably excludes intracranial hemorrhage, which is critical before initiating thrombolytic therapy.

questions.text: Why is the BOLD signal in fMRI considered an indirect measure of neural activity?
questions.answer: The BOLD signal reflects changes in blood oxygenation caused by vascular response to neural activity, not the neural firing itself, and occurs with a temporal delay.

questions.text: Why does MRI allow almost arbitrary contrast, while CT does not?
questions.answer: MRI contrast can be controlled via sequence parameters such as TR, TE, and flip angle, as well as tissue relaxation properties, whereas CT contrast is mainly determined by X-ray attenuation and material density.

questions.text: What is the main trade-off introduced by collimation in SPECT?
questions.answer: Collimation improves spatial resolution by restricting photon direction but significantly reduces sensitivity by discarding most emitted photons.

questions.text: Why are iterative reconstruction methods particularly suited for low-dose CT or PET?
questions.answer: Iterative methods explicitly model noise statistics and system physics, allowing acceptable image quality from fewer photons or projections compared to analytical methods.

questions.text: Why are confidence maps useful in ultrasound-guided robotics or tracking?
questions.answer: Confidence maps identify regions where the ultrasound signal is reliable, allowing algorithms or robots to ignore shadowed or unreliable areas and avoid tracking noise instead of anatomy.
